content: Hey @WG-async-foundations, it's time for our weekly triage meeting!
eholk couldn't make it today because of (what I believe is) a US holiday
So they asked me to take over today
I see some folks in chat already; say hi :wave: if you're here!
First up: announcements and introductions! - If you have something to share, now's the time!
And if you're new here (or haven't introduced yourself before), feel free to introduce yourself!
@eholk and I spent quite some time digging into https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/57017
and I think we more-or-less settled on a fix
too bad they're not here, I think they're going to prep the final PR
feeling good about that, though, since I think that this + the existing work on dropped objects represents a big ergonomic step forward
oh exciting! - that's been open for a very long time
yeah
the short version is that the existing analysis is overly conservative and treats every expression as it may be saved in a temporary
especially when matching on things, that can be a big overapproximation
since the lifetime of temporaries in the match "scrutinee" winds up being extended to cover the entire match
nods
we wound up with a relatively small diff but also plans for a larger overhaul of the analysis
I've heard eholk talk about "drop tracking" before, is that part of the larger overhaul, or this patch (if you know?)
wait, maybe that question doesn't make sense
nevermind haha, I guess it's all related
drop tracking is related but a separate effort
ah, I see!
it's basically another way that the current analysis was too conservative (it didn't have any idea what had been dropped)
after these two bits of work land, we're going to have to go through the remaining bugs, I'm not sure what kinds of remaining cases there are
I remember thinking there were at least 3 families of "over approximations", but it's a bit vague, maybe these were the main 2
well, there's another one that jumps to mind, but it requires some deeper edits -- anything you borrow we assume you borrow "forever", so to speak, even if the reference doesn't live across an await
ah, that's a big one too - good to know what isn't covered yet by the current set of patches
Did anyone have any other updates?
If not, then I think we can move on
@triagebot end-topic
(please work, one time)
okay, robots are unruly today I guess. We'll have to do this manually then.
Next up, New issue triage
That's an empty board :tada:
Good job us
(I think?)
Moving on to the next topic: Discussion on progress/blockers around sprint bugs
Our current sprint is here
I didn't have any items on this sprint, so I don't have much to share.
I guess I already shared mine :)
And I'm not seeing anyone else with sprint items around today.

@tmandry and I spent some more time on the "RPITIDT" (return position impl trait in dyn trait) writeup, I think we're just about done, though it needs polishing and explanatory material. Hopefully we'll knock that off today.
love the acronym, haha
and yes, I am just trying to make the acronyms as inscrutable as possible at this point
oh actually I think @tmandry is on vacation today :)
well, I'll push on it some more solo
hah yeah, I guess I'm surprised you're here today
I thought it was a US-wide national holiday
I am insufficiently patriotic to take President's Day as vacation
I see
Or maybe AWS is :P
/me gets himself in trouble

I guess maybe as a small update from me: last few weeks have been super hectic with deadlines. I've been spending some time today prioritizing what I need to work on, and that likely will be a lot of async work.
Anyway (:
I just put on my "to do" list: read all of yosh's blog posts
at least all the recent ones :)
I too have been kind of heads down
I've got a couple of half-finished followups re: cancellation and the like, too, would be fun to knock those off
I think I mentioned it before, but I'll do so again: I can make myself available if you ever want to sync chat / hack on things.
In case that would help working through blog posts, etc. too.
OK! I really want to spend some time playing with a nursery-like API in particular
I was just looking at the topics and thinking a good starting point would be writing about why a parallel (as opposed to concurrent) nursery is so dang hard to do
By "nursery" do you mean tasks groups with or without scope-captured values?
(not sure how to best describe what "scopes" do, but I hope it translates?)

nikomatsakis said:

OK! I really want to spend some time playing with a nursery-like API in particular

that sounds like a lot of fun tho!
anyway, it sounds like we've just about reached the end of the meeting. though we can keep chatting here if we want to
going to give it one last shot:
@triagebot end-meeting

Yoshua Wuyts [he/they] said:

(not sure how to best describe what "scopes" do, but I hope it translates?)

I mean scopes, really.
"structured concurrency"

iiiinteresting. I guess I view "scopes" as an optimization to not have to use smart pointers. But the general category of "things like TaskGroup, TaskScope, etc." as being a subset of types which implement structured concurrency.

nikomatsakis said:

too bad they're not here, I think they're going to prep the final PR

Yes, I'm planning to prep the final PR this afternoon
